div1.p: Pinto describes Reed's use of mosquitoes acquired from Finlay and the first experiments with volunteers.

div1.head: Recollection of the yellow fever experiments, by A.S. Pinto, [19--]
div1.p:
I think where so many have made a mistake as to the
time Reed got the mosquitoes from Findlay. It was many
weeks before the test was applied to us,

They first got the eggs or mosquitoes from Findlay and
incubated them and used all the first batch on what
was supposed to be non immune Spaniards, and it was
there was no result and Reed then wondered if they
were non immunes and then asked us to volunteer he said
Carroll and Lrzear had consented so I said sure I
would.

The six or seven supppsed immune Spaniards were the first
ones subjected to Findlay strain of mosquito given
the board by Findlay himself and they were larvae
I think.

The Spaniards used by Reed were recent arrivals in
Cuba and Reed doubted wheather they were immune or not
and if you remember when he got no effect from the Sp/
he was very much discouraged in the work, that was when
he left for Washington.

He was not in Cuba when Carroll came down with the
disease nor when Lezear died but returned as soon as he
could after Laxears death.

So you see many weeks elapsed from the reciept of the
first Findlay birds and the ones that were used on us.
However they were all Findlay strain of mosquito.
